body_html:
@Benyuel: I tried explicitly making the divisor float32 (in TensorFlow, the divisor is created using tf.constant), and the discrepancy still exists. Though if I test with float64, I get identical results just as you did.

And, as I said before,

if I use a = tf.constant(x, dtype=tf.float32) instead of tf.placeholder, the result seems correct.

It seems the divisor is innocent :).

Besides, the result of C-float division should be 0.9686274529 (Numpy result), rather than 0.9686275125 (TensorFlow result).
body_text:
@Benyuel: I tried explicitly making the divisor float32 (in TensorFlow, the divisor is created using tf.constant), and the discrepancy still exists. Though if I test with float64, I get identical results just as you did.
And, as I said before,

if I use a = tf.constant(x, dtype=tf.float32) instead of tf.placeholder, the result seems correct.

It seems the divisor is innocent :).
Besides, the result of C-float division should be 0.9686274529 (Numpy result), rather than 0.9686275125 (TensorFlow result).
body:
@Benyuel: I tried explicitly making the divisor `float32` (in TensorFlow, the divisor is created using `tf.constant`), and the discrepancy still exists. Though if I test with `float64`, I get identical results just as you did.

And, as I said before,

> if I use `a = tf.constant(x, dtype=tf.float32)` instead of `tf.placeholder`, the result seems correct.

It seems the divisor is innocent :).

Besides, the result of C-`float` division should be `0.9686274529` (Numpy result), rather than `0.9686275125` (TensorFlow result).
